unit_learning_outcomes.description: Explain key features of data and statistical models used in the fields of transcriptomics, epigenetics and microbiome analysis.
Describe core mechanisms of genetics, including mutation, recombination and selection.
Effectively communicate results of statistical analyses in genomics and related areas.
Use genome-wide SNP data to develop prediction models.
Describe the key data, models and inference goals of phylogenetics.

Use the Wright-Fisher and coalescent models of population genetics for simulation and
inference.
Perform a genetic association analysis, including the assessment of possibilities for confounding.
Access genomic data from public databases.
Explain the concept of heritability and its estimation.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Participation in online discussions around each module's exercises

enrolment_rules.description: (Admission to MBioStat or GradDipBioStat or GradCertBioStat) and (BCA805 or STAT8604) and (BCA804 or STAT8606) and (BCA808 or STAT8609)

data.description:
Statistical genomics is the application of statistical methods to understand genomes, their
structure, function and history, in many different scientific contexts, including: understanding
biological mechanisms in health and disease, optimising economic and welfare traits in animals and plants, learning about the history of humans and other organisms, and identifying individuals and their relatedness. Statistical genomics is characterised by large datasets, high-dimensional
regression models, stochastic processes, and computationally-intensive statistical methods. In this
unit we will learn about some of the relevant biology and terminology, the most important
mathematical models and inference methods in medical, population and evolutionary genetics,
how to test for association between genetic variants and outcomes of interest, genome-wide
statistical models to understand the genetic mechanisms underlying a trait and to predict
outcomes. We also introduce some other analyses “downstream” from the genome, including
gene expression and epigenetics, and microbiome analysis. The statistical package R will be
employed to perform analyses.
data.title: Statistical Genomics

description:

title: Statistical Genomics
